newsitem.title: SYRIA: Kuwait expects oil prices to remain high in 1997.
newsitem.headline: Kuwait expects oil prices to remain high in 1997.

text.p: Kuwait expects oil prices to stay high through 1997, Nasser al-Rodhan, deputy premier and finance minister said on Tuesday.
"Although oil prices are governed by several factors which are not fully controlled by the producers we believe prices in 1997 will maintain their current high levels," Rodhan said.
Speaking to Reuters in an interview in Damascus where he is on an official visit, Rodhan said market conditions were expected to continue to be favourable. He gave no details.
He said the continuation of the high prices would make "welcome positive impacts on the economy but the government would not make its calculations on the price rise."
He said the country's 1996-1997 June-July budget of 4.2 billion kuwaiti dinars ($14.02 billion) was based on a low oil price of $13 a barrel "to avoid any unexpected or sudden developments."

Kuwait has an production quota of two million barrels per day as set by the Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC). Kuwaiti crude is prices at a differential to Saudi Arabia's Arab medium grade, currently priced for European customers at a discount to North Sea Brent equating to around $20 a barrel.

"The high prices would certainly improve the country's national income which depends for more than 90 per cent on the oil revenue but our budget calculations are made on a price of $13 per barrel," the minister said.
The price for Brent has recently held within a range of $20-25, compared to prices of between $15-20 that have been dominant for the last 10 years.
Rodhan said Kuwait would base next year's budget at $13 a barrel and would project a spending increase of 10 percent over this year's budget.
This year's deficit of 1.2 billion dinar would also be cut by 250 dinars in the next year's budget, the minister said.

"We hope to bring the deficit in the government's budget to the zero point in the 1999-2000 budget and we will continue with a programme to increase projected spending by 10 percent until then," Rodhan said.
"We hope to go on with our plans unless there are any surprises or unexpected international developments," the minister said.
